awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Molecular Photovoltaics: A Lipid-Based Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Wei Zhan of Auburn University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry to develop a new class of molecular photovoltaic systems using chromophores (porphyrins), electron acceptors (fullerenes) and donors (ferrocenes) assembled within solid-supported thin lipid bilayer films. Organothiol adsorbates on gold will be used to adjust the surface properties of the solid support including polarity, charge, work function, redox properties, and degree of electronic conjugation.  Photocurrent generation will be correlated with molecular and bilayer structural changes.  

Understanding the mechanisms of charge transfer and the relationship between film structure and photocurrent generation will shed light on important current-limiting processes, and help improve the efficiency of photovoltaic devices.  The educational initiative includes classes and demonstrations to broaden awareness of alternative energy generation, and outreach activities for a broad audience in Alabama.

Motivation

Natural photosynthetic organisms, such as green plants and algae, use light energy from the Sun to fix carbon dioxide, produce oxygen and chemical fuels with exceedingly high efficiencies. In this NSF-supported research, we were motivated to mimic several key steps in photosynthesis using a class of natural component called lipids. Unlike photosynthetic proteins, which are often fragile and hard to obtain artificially, lipids can be synthesized and obtained in large quantities. Another attractive feature of lipids is their ability to self-assemble, which originates from the fact that these molecules contain both water-liking (hydrophilic) and water-hating (hydrophobic) groups. Indeed, in water hundreds of thousands of these molecules often group together to form various nanostructures such as lipid bilayers. Another distinctive feature that separates our effort from previous ones is that we form these bilayers directly on electrodes. This way, we were able to develop a new class of hybrid molecular photovoltaic systems combining natural species – lipids, with synthetic materials often used in organic photovoltaics. This approach has not only offered us a powerful window to scrutinize many key factors in light-to-electrochemical energy conversion processes, but also provided us ample opportunities to interact with and educate the general public about our energy future.

Significant Outcomes

This six-year journey has yielded at least four significant outcomes.

1. Novel Molecular Photovoltaic Systems Based on Electrode-Supported Lipid Bilayers. Our research in the past few years has produced three new photovoltaic models using various electrode-supported lipid bilayers (Figure 1). With these, we're able to advance the utility of lipids in molecular photovoltaics.

2. Analytical Power of Hybrid-Bilayer Based Photoconversion Systems. Here, the assembly is consisted of precisely one monolayer of thiols and lipids each. Their packing order is also fixed, with lipids on top of thiols that are directly grafted on the underlying gold surface. Each monolayer in addition displays a preferential orientation, thanks to the Au-S bonding at the bottom and the lipid/water interface at the top. This flexible and controllable molecular design has enabled us to study several important parameters in photoconversion processes, including interfacial dipole, redox level and electronic communication between natural (lutein) and synthetic (fullerene) photoactive components.

3. Mimicking Photosynthesis with Supercomplexed Lipid Nanoassemblies. One limitation of the above single-lipid-bilayer based systems is their poor light absorption, which lets most incoming photons pass and thus be wasted. To address this issue, we further developed a two-layer system, in which the liposomes at the top serve as the light-harvesting unit and the bottom lipid bilayer takes care of the charge separation (Figure 2). This design resembles a natural photosynthetic system, green sulfur bacteria, with which we’re able to achieve very respectable photoconversion efficiency.
